text: Hey y'all, today we're gonna do a comparative analysis of EQ8, the Ableton
stock EQ plugin, and FabFilter Pro-Q3. So a little bit of background, I was
using EQ8 for the last like four years on everything that I was working on, and
it's basically just like a bare-bones EQ. It doesn't have a ton of bells and
whistles, but it really just gets the job done. So I didn't think that
there was much to be improved upon, I guess. I didn't see the point of
switching over to a different plugin, and then about a month ago I started
demoing the EQ, or the Pro-Q3 EQ plugin, and it's honestly pretty sick. So maybe
I'm definitely gonna buy it. So let's look at the EQs here. So I have one
of my tracks, one of my masters here in this session. So what we'll do is just play it, and
we'll look at the different features of both plugins, and you can see for
yourself. So, EQ8. You can double-click on the plugin in the Ableton window, and it
gives you a nice big view of all your audio information. It comes with four
nodes, kind of built in. First one's a shelf, then you've got some bells, and this one is also a shelf.
They're numbered, so what you do is go through...if you click one, it highlights it down here, and you can adjust aspects of your EQ.
Turning up the gain, adjusting your Q, and you can also add in more nodes by turning them on, and then they show up in the corner.
So it's pretty straightforward workflow, and I guess that's why I've been using it
for so many years. It just works, you know, and you don't have to...it doesn't have a huge learning curve.
Oh, there's also this feature where you can solo the node that you're working with, just to hear what it's doing to the audio information, which I guess is pretty easy.
I've never really used it that much, but then you can turn on and off the Spectro.
So yeah, that's EQ8, sort of like a workhorse EQ. So we'll turn that off. Now, Pro-Q 3. Open it up. You can see there's just a lot going on here already.
You've got a VU meter in the side. You've got a piano roll at the bottom, which is pretty cool. You can toggle it on and off.
And how it works is you turn it on and then you just hover your mouse over the...oh, there you go.
You hover your mouse over the audio information and it'll generate the musical notes that you're hitting.
So you can see how that could be useful, right, when you're working on a track. And you can turn that off if you don't like it.
My favorite thing about this plugin is this feature called...if you hover over it, it's called Spectrum Grab.
And basically, as you can see, it says if you hover your mouse over, it'll automatically enter this.
And what it does is you just let it sit there and it grabs the spectra and shows you where everything's peaking.
And then if you want, you can go in and basically grab a node and reduce some of that resonance.
And then each node generates its own little floating thing here where you have your own EQ control.
You can change what it is. So you've got all these things. You can turn it on and off.
And you can also do a lot of the stuff here. So you can turn it back on. You can solo it.
Pretty cool. And then you can change basically the shape.
Now, one thing I like about Pro-Q3 is it has EQ capabilities that EQ doesn't come with.
So for example, this is one I've been using a lot since I got it. Basically, it is like a tilt.
So you can adjust the frequency balance of a track or a group of tracks using this tilt control, which is pretty powerful.
Sometimes you just want to reduce a little bit of the bass, but you don't want to impact the mix too much.
You can just kind of toss it in there. It's pretty nice.
And then the cool thing is that you have two pieces of information that you're grabbing all the time with this.
First is you have your standard spectra, right?
But then once you start applying EQ, you get the ghost, basically.
So you see where it was before in the background, and then you see what your EQ is actually doing to the signal.
So it gives you a lot of visual information to work with.
And I find that a pretty compelling feature because, you know, yeah, of course, you should be using your ears when you're mixing.
But sometimes your ears are only so powerful in terms of understanding what the work is that you're doing, especially in the low end.
Like, I know a lot of us don't have the most accurate bass referencing available to us, right?
So when you're looking at bass frequencies, you know, it's useful to see what's going on when you're messing with EQ
and what three decibels actually impacts, you know?
There's a lot more to this EQ. There's like a multi-band or like a dynamic EQ function here as well that I haven't really messed with that much.
But so far I'm finding that just these features that I've outlined already have sold me on this 100%.
Now, another thing that's really interesting about this is that you can have multiple instances of Pro-Q3 across your mix.
So say you have one of them on your drums, one of them on your bass, one of them on your guitar, or you have two guitars.
Then what you can do is use this thing called Show Collisions.
And Show Collisions basically, you toggle it on and it will show you if you have frequencies that are colliding with one another in your mix.
That could potentially be causing masking. Obviously this isn't like a replacement for listening to your mix.
But if you're importing a track with say like 150 different instruments, or you're just starting out on a mix,
you can toss the Pro-Q3 on to a bunch of different instances or groups and then you can see what's going on pretty quickly.
See if there's buildup and just go quickly tackle that first, right?
So I think these are just some really smart features that are the reason why pros are using this.
So with that, I'm going to end this little comparison video.
If you like what I'm doing, please subscribe to my channel.
Check out some of my other stuff. Give me a like.
Share this with your friends. Your friends are into producing.
And yeah, thanks so much. Peace.
